data.text: Contents
Children and Young People under the Age of 18 Years ............................................... 9
Introduction

Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust is committed to continually providing high quality healthcare for all patients whilst they are in the Trust, whilst also supporting the staff that provide this care. The aim of the policy is to safeguard patients and staff during the delivery of intimate care, or examinations, investigations and procedures that are deemed to be of an intimate nature.

All patients regardless of age, gender, ethnic background, culture, cognitive function, sexual orientation, or marital status have the right to have their privacy and dignity respected. Respect, explanation, consent, and privacy are more important than the need for a chaperone for the majority of patients.

There is guidance from the General Medical Council (GMC, 2013) and the Nursing and Midwifery Council (NMC, 2015) that suggests that wherever possible a patient undergoing an intimate examination should be offered a chaperone or invited to bring a relative or friend to a consultation.

Many healthcare interventions, by their nature, can be classified as intimate, and misunderstandings and misinterpretation of actions can occasionally lead to allegations of abuse. A lack of understanding with regards to a patient's social or cultural background may lead to a feeling of vulnerability and confusion and this document serves to provide a best practice guideline for staff involved in intimate care episodes.
A chaperone should always be present for any examination where the patient lacks capacity. This also applies if the patient is a minor (person under the age of 18).

Prior to any intimate examination, the patient should have the procedure explained to them fully by the healthcare professional, including discussion of who will be present. As a teaching Trust, there will be occasions where medical or nursing students will be present in the clinical areas; however patients should have the opportunity to refuse to allow them to witness any such examination without feeling awkward. Thus patient's permission should be sought before the examination and record that the patient has given it.

This policy has been developed to ensure that where intimate and personal care is necessary, care is provided in a respectful, sensitive and professional manner and that a chaperone is available for such times that it is identified necessary. By encouraging the use of a chaperone, the Trust wishes to promote a culture of openness between patients and healthcare professionals.

Should a patient request a chaperone, one should be provided; alternatively, the examination may need to be rescheduled. If it is not possible for a chaperone to be present, discussion should be had with the patient and the outcome documented clearly in the healthcare records. If the patient is offered and does not want a chaperone it is important to record that the offer was made and declined. If a chaperone is refused a healthcare professional cannot usually insist that one is present, and many will examine the patient without one. If a clinician is unhappy to examine a patient without a chaperone and one is not available, the examination should be postponed, and the event fully documented in the patient's healthcare record.
Scope
The aim of the policy is to safeguard patients and staff during the delivery of intimate care, or examinations, investigations and procedures that are deemed to be of an intimate nature.
A chaperone should always be present for any examination where the patient lacks capacity. This also applies if the patient is a minor (person under the age of 18).
Definitions

table_items.text: There is no common definition of a chaperone, and their role varies considerably depending on the needs of the patient, the healthcare professional and the procedure being carried out. In essence a chaperone is an impartial third party person who is present during a patient examination and/or treatment for benefit of both the patient and member of staff. A chaperone is an adult person. Children should not be used as chaperones, even in exceptional circumstances. It may be helpful for the chaperone to be the same gender as the patient, but this is not mandatory.

Intimate care is defined as care tasks associated with bodily functions, body products and personal hygiene that requires direct or indirect contact or exposure of the intimate parts of the body including breasts, genitalia or rectum Examples of this include: Dressing and undressing; Assisting a patient to use the toilet, catheter care; Assisting a patient with personal hygiene; Changing sanitary pads; Changing continence pads; Stoma care; Inserting pessaries, suppositories or enemas; Application or renewal of dressings in an intimate area; Completing an electro cardiogram (ECG); Undertaking full body assessment for body map completion to identify wounds, pressure ulcers, bruises.

Intimate examination includes the physical examination of breasts, genitalia or rectum, although in some cultures other areas may be classified as intimate. Intimate examinations and procedures can be stressful and embarrassing for patients.
An intimate procedure would be described as an invasive procedure of the breast, genitalia or rectum.

data.text: As healthcare practitioners we need to be sensitive to what our patients may think of as intimate (GMC 2013).
Role & Responsibilities within the Trust
Divisional Medical Directors:

The Divisional Medical Director is responsible for ensuring that the necessary systems, processes, training and competency assessment (where appropriate) are available to ensure that all medical and dental staff are able to comply with the contents of this document. In addition, he/she is responsible for ensuring that the monitoring and audit of this document is undertaken and reported in the appropriate forum as indicated in the document.
Care Group Director of Nursing:

The Director of Nursing is responsible for ensuring that the necessary systems, processes, training and competency assessment (where appropriate) are available to ensure that all non-medical staff (nurses, midwives and allied health professionals) are able to comply with the contents of this document.
Deputy Director of Operations (DDO)

The ADO's are responsible for implementing the systems and processes required throughout the Divisions to ensure that this document is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial action implemented as appropriate.
Deputy and Associate Directors of Nursing (ADoN)

The DDONS and ADON's are responsible for ensuring that the policy is disseminated throughout the Division and that the required monitoring and audit are undertaken, with the resources provided to support this.
General Manager/ Deputy General Manager/ Service Managers
Assistant Service Mangers and department managers are responsible for implementing this document and for monitoring the impact on the service and reporting compliance with the document.
Head of Therapies:

The Head of Therapies is responsible for ensuring that this document is fully implemented at department level. This will include making sure any relevant and necessary training is given and received, that the introduction of the document is monitored and therefore assessing the impact this is having on service delivery. In addition, the head of therapies is responsible for ensuring that the required monitoring and audit are undertaken and reported through the relevant governance system.
Professional Midwifery Advocates:

Professional Midwifery Advocates provide a mechanism of support and guidance to women and midwives. Professional Midwifery Advocates are experienced practising midwives who have undertaken further education in order to supervise midwifery services and to advise and support midwives and women in their care choices.
Matrons:

Matrons are responsible for ensuring that all nursing staff, including Clinical Nurse Specialists comply with the contents of this document and for taking action when this is not the case. The matron will make sure that all necessary training is provided.
Medical Staff
The Consultant holds ultimate responsibility for ensuring that all members of the medical team follow the guidelines contained within this document.
Senior Sisters/Nursing Staff

The Senior Sister/nurse in charge is accountable for the safe care and management of patients in clinical areas. They are therefore responsible for ensuring that all staff within these areas comply with this document and for implementing a system to provide assurance that this is the case.
Role of Clinical Staff

All clinical staff have a responsibility to act in the patient's best interests and are accountable for their actions. They should provide safe and effective care, while working within the law and respecting the human rights of individuals. All staff should be prepared to make arrangements for patients to have a chaperone during intimate examinations.
Role of the chaperone
All clinical staff who have Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) clearance are able to perform the role of formal chaperone.
Any member of clinical staff (including healthcare assistants) familiar with the policy may undertake chaperoning. Administrative staff should not chaperone.
All external agencies providing clinical staff to the Trust are obliged to ensure that they are DBRS approved as detailed in the agency framework.

The role of the chaperone in each individual examination must be made clear to both the chaperone and the patient. Staff should be familiar with what is required of them prior to any examination beginning. The role of the chaperone can include:
Providing emotional comfort and reassurance to the patient;
To assist the patient with undressing;
To assist with the examination, by passing relevant instruments to the clinician during minor procedures;

To identify unusual or unacceptable behaviour by the healthcare professional although it is not the role of the chaperone to judge the appropriateness of the examination to the patients' healthcare needs;
To ensure the patients' needs are met throughout the process;
Be the patient's advocate.
Formal chaperone
A formal chaperone will be required when examining or undertaking a procedure for a patient:
Requiring an intimate examination;
Who is semi-conscious or unconscious;
Who is intoxicated with alcohol or drugs which include those which are known to have a hallucinogenic or sedating effect;
Who is a child or young people under the age of 18; this includes when an examination for child protection procedures is being undertaken;
With a learning disability;
Who is considered to be vulnerable or at risk (including individuals that lack capacity);
Whose first language is not English;
Who appears nervous or to have reservations about the examination.
5.1.1 A formal chaperone must be present whenever an intimate examination/procedure is to take place, regardless of the gender of the examiner.
5.1.2 Careful consideration should be given to patients who have previously had a traumatic intimate examination or have been sexually assaulted in the past.
5.1.3 Family or friends should not undertake the role of formal chaperone, although they may be present in an informal capacity at intimate examinations at the invitation of the patient.

5.1.4 In a legal situation the ability of the Trust to defend a false accusation may be jeopardised if a formal chaperone is not present when required. Where an examination is inappropriate or not consented it may constitute a criminal or civil offence.
Informal chaperone
5.6.1 This role of informal chaperone can be fulfilled by a relative, friend or other member of staff.

5.6.2 For patients with a learning disability or those that lack capacity a familiar individual such as a family member of carer may act as an informal chaperone as they will be familiar with the individual's needs. A formal chaperone is still required in this instance as per the guidance above.
5.6.3 Informal chaperone can be requested by any patient who has not been assessed as requiring a formal chaperone.
5.6.4 Children should not act as an informal chaperone for a parent or sibling.
Children and Young People under the Age of 18 Years
It is mandatory for all children and young people under the legal age of consent (16 years) to be seen in the presence of another adult. This may be a parent, acting as an informal chaperone.
A parent or formal chaperone must be present for any physical examination; the child should not be examined unaccompanied.
Any intimate examination must be carried out in the presence of a formal chaperone.
Parents or guardians must receive an appropriate explanation of the procedure in order to obtain their informed consent to examination.
A parent or carer or someone already known and trusted by the child may also be present for reassurance.
For young adults, who are deemed to have mental capacity, the guidance that relates to adults is applicable.

Children and young adults being prepared for ‘transition' to adult services (usually after the age of 14 years) may be seen for consultation or assessment without their parents/ carer at their request and with parental consent. That they are undertaking transition, as per Trust policy, should be recorded in the child health record.
However, any physical or intimate examination requires a formal chaperone.

If a young person specifically requests review without a chaperone, this must be discussed with them and their carer, and documented in the notes. Physical/intimate examination should not proceed without a chaperone.

In the case of people with learning disabilities/autism, best practice would indicate a planned approach to all investigative interventions. Therefore contact with the hospital Liaison LD specialist or safeguarding lead nurse could be enacted in order to facilitate an improved and effectual patient experience.

This patient group are vulnerable and issues may arise with physical examination; therefore reasonable adjustments must be made which includes the provision of an informal or formal chaperone; their need can be identified prior to any procedure or examination.

A chaperone will be necessary to support the clinical examination; the chaperone will provide support and reassurance to the person, witness the continuing consent to a procedure, and may provide practical help to the clinician. The role of the chaperone provides safeguards to both the patient and the healthcare professional during consultation, examination, treatment and care and may provide additional protection for the health care professional from people with learning disabilities/autism who are known to present with behaviours which are challenging to the service.

For people with a learning disability/autism, a family member; friend or advocate may act as an informal chaperone as they will be familiar with the individual's needs, fears and methods of communication. Formal chaperones include paid carers; LD practitioner, community LD nurse or other familiar health professional. The choice of using either an informal or formal chaperone should be considered on an individual basis, whilst acknowledging the need to safeguard such vulnerable groups.

Many people with learning disability will still have capacity to give consent for themselves given the appropriate support. For those who do not have capacity, decisions should be made based on the key principles of the MCA (2005).

A vulnerable adult who is deemed to have capacity has the right to consent or refuse assessment, examination and/or treatment and may also make their own decision regarding the presence of a chaperone; in such circumstances their right to decline a chaperone must be respected however the healthcare professional should decide whether it is appropriate to continue with the examination. This must be recorded within the healthcare records identifying that the presence of a chaperone was declined and the action taken.

By checking the information held within either the patient's Health Action Plan or hospital passport, information can be accessed on preferred communication method and choice of carer/chaperone can be established. The document will highlight any known risks and there will also be reference to any consent issues which may help with assessing the person's mental capacity.
Maintaining Privacy and Dignity
In order to maintain privacy and dignity the following points should be considered:
Provide the patient with a private space in which to undress and dress themselves;
Pull curtain across ensuring full closure;
Provide the patient with a gown if necessary;
Close the doors to any public areas;
Avoid over-exposure of the patient (use clothing as a temporary cover);
Only help the patient to remove or replace clothing if they ask for or appear to need help;
Always knock or call before entering;
Avoid any delay to the procedure taking place.
During an intimate examination healthcare professionals should:
Offer reassurance;
Be courteous;
Keep discussion relevant;
Avoid unnecessary personal comments;
Encourage question and discussion;
Remain alert to verbal and non-verbal indications of distress from the patient which may indicate withdrawal of consent.
Remote consultations

Standards of good practice apply to both face to face and remote consultations. A remote or video consultation does not negate the need to offer a chaperone and the same principles for a face to face consultation would apply. A chaperone involved in a remote consultation must be able to fulfil their role in reassuring the patient and raising any concerns.

Consideration should also be given to logistical, technical and security issues involved in a chaperone joining a remote consultation as a third party should it not be possible to be physically present alongside the clinician conducting the consultation.
Communication and Record Keeping

The most common cause of complaints is a failure on the patient's part to understand what the healthcare practitioner was doing in the process of treating them. It is essential that the healthcare professional explains the nature of the examination to the patient and offers them a choice whether to proceed with that examination at that time. The patient will then be able to give an informed consent to continue with the consultation.
Details of the examination including presence/absence of chaperone, name of the chaperone and information given must be clearly documented in the patient records.

If it is not possible for a chaperone to be present, discussion should be had with the patient and the outcome documented clearly in the healthcare records. If the patient is offered a chaperone and declines the offer it is important to record that the offer was made and declined. If a chaperone is refused a healthcare professional cannot usually insist that one is present and should consider if they wish to proceed with the intervention/examination.
If a clinician is unhappy to examine a patient without a chaperone and one is not available, the examination should be postponed, and the event fully documented in the patient's healthcare record.
Special Circumstances
Intimate examinations of anaesthetised patients
If an intimate examination is to be performed under anaesthetic, the patient must have consented to this in writing prior to the anaesthetic being administered.
Intimate examinations of patients without capacity to consent
If appropriate a familiar individual or member of the patient's family may be able to support the patient to have the required examination.

10.2.1 When a patient is declining treatment and may lack mental capacity, an MCA must be completed, and decision taken accordingly in the patients' best interests in line with the principles of the Mental Capacity Act 2005.
10.2.2 If there is any doubt about any aspect of chaperoning a vulnerable patient, seek further advice from the Trust Learning Disability Nurse; Dementia CNS or Safeguarding team.
Training requirements

As each department within the Trust performs many examinations for differing reasons, training should be specific to the area where the chaperoning is taking place. It is the responsibility of the Nurse in charge to ensure that all staff allocated as chaperones are adequately inducted into the Trust and trained to chaperone within their area. Staff can chaperone in an area once they are deemed competent to do so by one of the nursing staff who has observed their practice. There should be written documentation supporting this within local staff files, and arrangements in place for staff to address any concerns with their line manager in a timely fashion.
Monitoring and Audit

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Instances of non- compliance with the policy should be recorded via Datix and investigated accordingly.
The department where non- compliance occurred

Divisions will be required to monitor local compliance against this policy at an operational level which includes reporting incidents of non-compliance through their respective divisional governance systems.

data.text: Approval and Implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Matrons Group which is the specialist group with the authority to approve Trust-wide guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Matrons Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality Impact Assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to appendix 1)
References
Care Quality Commission (2015)  The fundamental standards online at: http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/fundamental-standards
General Medical Council (2013) Intimate examinations and chaperones.  Intimate examinations and chaperones - GMC (gmc-uk.org)
HCPC (2016)  Standards of conduct, performance and ethics online at:  Standards of conduct, performance and ethics | (hcpc-uk.org)

NMC (2015) The Code; Professional Standards of practice and behaviour for nurses and midwives. Online at:  The Code: Professional standards of practice and behaviour for nurses, midwives and nursing associates - The Nursing and Midwifery Council (nmc.org.uk)
Mental Capacity Act (2005) Online at: Mental Capacity Act 2005 (legislation.gov.uk)

What are you proposing to change?
To standardise three site policies into one MSE policy
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
Merge of three site policies to create an MSE Trust policy
Who benefits from this change and how?
Clinical staff will only need to work to one policy regardless of what site they are on
